Jobs Marketplace

  • What is the Jobs Marketplace?

    GCconnex - Help Content > Jobs Marketplace

    Jobs Marketplace is a public service-wide Internet forum, created within  GCconnex, that enables employees to network professionally across departments.



    Jobs Marketplace is intended for at-level mobility (e.g. indeterminate and term deployments, secondments, and assignments), as well as casual employment, students seeking employment opportunities, micro-mission opportunities as well as a reference page to other sources of talent that managers and HR professionals may wish to explore, including active pools from other departments. Jobs Marketplace can also be used as a tool to facilitate alternations during workforce adjustment situations.

     Jobs Marketplace facilitates people management by improving access for managers to inventories of motivated employees ready and willing to take on new challenges. It also enables employee engagement, discussion and learning, both through the potential opportunities that Jobs Marketplace offers, and through the use of the tool itself.

    The Jobs Marketplace has a new automated matching tool, the Career ConneXions Opportunities Platform. This is a tool that quickly matches at-level mobility (i.e. micro-missions and job swapping) and development (i.e. mentoring and job shadowing) opportunities with talented employees by leveraging the content in employees’ GCconnex profiles. Employees are encouraged to “opt in” to the professional development and at-level mobility opportunities in their profiles to take full advantage of this tool.


     Jobs Marketplace is being enhanced to make it a one-stop shop for managers and employees to navigate new features for public service staffing, resourcing and development. Check Jobs Marketplace regularly to take advantage of the new features and information! 

  • How does the Jobs Marketplace work?

    GCconnex - Help Content > Jobs Marketplace

    Jobs Marketplace provides a space for employees to advertise their interest in finding a job and for managers to advertise vacancies/opportunities. Employees can search available opportunities and respond if they meet the necessary qualifications. Likewise, managers can seek out and communicate with employees who post on the Job Seekers’ forum.


    Once a candidate is identified for an opportunity, all subsequent communication should take place directly between the hiring manager and the employee by email or telephone rather than through Jobs Marketplace. The departmental human resources policies and/or procedures for deployments, secondments, assignments, alternations, casual employment or term employment apply, including the required documentation. 


  • What's the purpose of each major section of the Jobs Marketplace?

    GCconnex - Help Content > Jobs Marketplace

    Opportunities Posting: This forum is for managers to post their at-level interdepartmental job opportunities. 


    Job Seeker's Forum: This forum is for job seekers to advertise their availability and post their contact details. 


    Alternation Forum: This forum was created to facilitate communication between affected employees and employees looking to leave the core public administration through alternation.


    Micro-Missions: A tool to support short-term, voluntary, and task-based opportunities for employees to contribute to work outside of their normal duties and for managers to leverage talent outside their normal teams. 


    Other Sources of Talent: A page that provides links to other initiatives/sites that have sources of talent that may be valuable to the managers, including the Central Repository of Active Federal Public Service Pools.


    Career ConneXions Opportunities Platform: A new automated matching tool that quickly matches at-level mobility (i.e. micro-missions and job swapping) and development (i.e. mentoring and job shadowing) opportunities with talented employees by leveraging the content in employees’ GCconnex profiles. Scroll down for more information about each type of opportunity and tutorials for using the tool.

Getting Started

  • What is my GCcollab profile for?

    GCcollab - Help Content > Getting Started

    GCcollab is all about establishing connections. When you connect with other professionals in the public service, you are gaining more knowledge and insight since you are interacting with colleagues. Have a question? Ask someone on GCcollab. Want to know about upcoming events in your area? You can find out this information on GCcollab as well. In other words, your connections on GCcollab can help accelerate your career. 


    If you are looking to get more connections on GCcollab, it is crucial that you complete your profile. Make it easier for people to find you by including your picture, name and location. Be sure to add a summary of your education, skills, and experience.


    GCcollab profile example


    This is a very complete profile and doing so is helpful in showcasing your background and accomplishments. 



    We recommend that you at least add a picture to your profile. Many people are not used to putting pictures of themselves on social media sites, let alone one for public servants. But this helps other users to find us more easily. It doesn’t have to be a picture of you, but something that identifies you. It can be very frustrating sometimes trying to find a user through all the gray silhouettes.


    Profile Completeness

    Your GCcollab profile shows your Profile Strength as a percentage. It can be found on the right-hand side of your personal profile. It also indicates whether you have an avatar and "About me" completed on your profile.

    Click "See details" to see the breakdown of the following sections of your profile:

    • Basic Profile
    • Skills
    • Education
    • Work experience


  • How do I access my profile?

  • How do I edit my profile?

    GCcollab - Help Content > Getting Started

    Your basic profile includes your contact information and links to external social media platforms.


    Profile Tab

    On your profile, underneath the Basic Profile and Avatar, there are seven tabs that link your colleagues to information about you. The default tab is the one for Profile. 

    The Profile Tab is the part of your profile where you can let your colleagues learn more about who you are and where you came from.


    About Me

    The first section within the tab allows you to write a paragraph about yourself. You can display a bit of your personality here, by talking about your hobbies and interests.


    Education

    The education section provides small windows of information that relate to diplomas, degrees, or certificates you have earned. You can input where you studied, for how long, and what your area of expertise is. This feature can be used for networking purposes, or even finding old classmates.


    Work Experience

    The work experience section is similar in functionality to the education section. Users can input previous job titles, employers, and describe the aspects of their work. This feature can be used for networking purposes, or even finding old colleagues. 


    Skills

    The new skills section allows users to input various skills they believe to hold (up until a maximum number of fifteen) colleagues of the user can endorse their colleagues for skills they have seen displayed, giving each skill credibility and a recommendation.


    Portfolio Tab

    The Portfolio Tab allows users to upload various projects, such as documents or even infographics,to display the various expertise of the user. This can provide a visual and practical aspect to your profile - potentially drawing in future employers interested in your skills!


    Widgets Tab

    In this tab, you can customize which widgets you want visible, where on your profile they should be, and how much they will display. For example, you could choose to show your Activity, Colleagues, Groups, Bookmarks, or maybe you want to show Colleagues only. Your GCcollab profile reflects you!

    • How do I create an event?

      GCcollab - Help Content > Collaboration and Networking

      In GCcollab, you can post your events in a Group calendar or site-wide calendar. With its government and external user base, GCcollab can be a very useful promotion tool for your events!


      How to access the Calendar

      You can access the event planning page in three ways: 


      Your Profile

      1. Click on your profile icon, near the top right of the page.
      2. Click on My Profile
      3. Select Events

      Main GCcollab navigation menu

      1. Click on More in the top navigation bar
      2. Select Event calendar


      In a Group

      1. Go to the Group in which you want to post an event
      2. Click on More
      3. Select Events


      How to post an event

      1.  Click on Add event
      2.  Fill out the form describing details of your event such as the Title, Venue, and a Brief description
      3.  Click Save to finish

      Tips

      • Brief description: acts as a short summary of the event. It should catch the attention of users as they browse through events. Try and keep this to a single sentence for each language used (5-15 words each).
      • Long description: acts as a full description what the event is and any other identifying information. Try to be as detailed and transparent as possible. Any acronyms should be written out in full before continuing with the acronym. In the case of a bilingual event, remember to post the description in both official languages.
      • Tags: to get the most publicity out of your events, it's best to use tags. Tags are essentially key words that reflect the purpose of your event. They are identifiers that make your post searchable. Here are some quick tips on how to use tags: 
        • Separate each tag with a comma and space 
        • Tags should be words or short phrases people will likely search when looking for an event like yours 
        • Remember to make tags bilingual in order for as many people as possible to be able to find your event

    • How do notifications work?

      GCcollab - Help Content > Manage Account Settings

      Auto-subscription to content

      On GCcollab, you will automatically be subscribed to notifications (both on site and by email) when you:  

      1. Create new content
        You will receive notifications related to the content you create when someone adds a comment or replies to it (e.g. comments  on a blog or  file, reply to a discussion topics, etc.). These notifications can be managed from the “Personal Notifications” section.
      2. Join a group
        After joining a group, you will start receiving notifications related to all new content added to that group, such as a new blog post, a new discussion topic, a new page, etc. These notifications can be managed from the “Group Notifications” section.

        Note: you will not receive notifications for each subsequent comments/replies made on that content unless you: 
        1.  Manually subscribe to the content using the bell icon; 
        2.  You post a comment about that content; 
        3.  Post a reply to that content; 
        4.  Share that content.

      3.  Comment on, and reply to, or update content You will start receiving notifications related to content you comment on, and reply to, or update content.

        Note: you will not receive notifications related content that you “like” or “share”. These notifications can be managed from the “Other Content Subscriptions” section


      Subscribing to specific content from a page

      On GCcollab, you also have the option to instantaneously subscribe (or unsubscribe) to notifications directly from the page you are navigating.  

      1. Go to the content of interest
      2. Click on the bell: 
      • to subscribe - the bell will become a solid colour

      • to unsubscribe - the bell will become greyed out with a line going across

      To manage your notifications settings, see this article.

      FAQs

      • What type of documents/information can we post/share on the GCTools?

        About the GCTools > FAQs

        Since the GCTools are on a Government of Canada internal network, employees should follow the same rules as if they were sending a document by email. 


        As the GCTools are not on a secure network, you should not post any content rated above Protected A. Making a document or information “private” or for “group members” only in GCconnex or GCollab doesn’t allow you to circumvent this requirement. 


      • Are the GCTools accessible to employees with disabilities?

        About the GCTools > FAQs
        Public servants who make use of screen readers and other assistive devices are able to successfully use GCpedia, GCconnex, and GCcollab.


        As administrators, the GCTools Team is making all possible efforts to ensure that the Tools are can be accessed and used by all users. 


        The GCTools Team partnered with Statistics Canada to do accessibility testing on GCconnex. While GCconnex received a relatively high compliance score, Stats Can identified a number of areas that we can address to improve the accessibility of the site. With the help of Stats Can, our technical team implemented a number of key accessibility improvements during the Spring of 2015. 


        As a contributor, you should ensure that the content you post to the GCTools is done in a manner that is as accessible as possible to all users. Be conscious of the fact that some specialized formatting or media types may significantly increase the risk of accessibility issues.


      • Is there duplication with GCDocs?

        About the GCTools > FAQs

        No. GCDOCS is an official repository for information of business value. GCpedia, GCconnex, and GCcollab are for transitory information. 


        If content is posted on GCpedia for sharing with people from other departments is of business value, it should also have been saved in your departmental document repository first. 


      • Why can’t I use a pseudonym on the GCTools?

        About the GCTools > FAQs

        The GCTools are professional networking and collaborative platforms. Collaboration is based on trust and we should all be easily identifiable. Don’t forget that your user profile is linked to your email address, and that your full user name (usually RealFirstName.RealLastName) appears anyway in the address bar; Therefore, there is no point in trying to hide behind a screen name. 


        When you register, you have to accept the Terms and Conditions. Using your real name is part of the conditions you agree to when signing-up.


      • What happens if employees post inappropriate or rude content?

        About the GCTools > FAQs
        It is very rare that any inappropriate content is posted to the GCTools, in part because we do not allow anonymous posting.


        Remember, just because you might not agree with a comment, it doesn’t mean it is inappropriate. However, if you see content that violates our terms and conditions of use for the GCTools, please notify the GCTools team and we will take appropriate action as warranted to either contact the individual who created the content and/or to remove the content.


      • Storing or distributing documents: should I use GCconnex or GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > FAQs

        If you want to share documents openly to all public servants or in a visually structured way, GCpedia is probably better if you are comfortable with creating pages in MediaWiki (you can also reuse code from pages you like to make it easier!). 


        If the documentation is shared through a working group/committee, then GCconnex is probably better. Members will look for files in a folder format the same way as they would do in a regular computer drive system.


      • Our department already has SharePoint (or another collaboration tool). Should we still use the GCTools?

        About the GCTools > FAQs

        Yes! Sometimes the departmental tools will be the right tools, sometimes the GCTools will be the appropriate tools. It all depends on what you are doing and who you are trying to reach.


        Departmental collaboration tools do not allow for interdepartmental collaboration. The GCTools are free for departments to use and are the only tools available to share information and collaboration with federal government employees across all public service, in all regions. 


      • Am I able to access the GCTools from home?

        About the GCTools > FAQs
        The GCpedia and GCconnex are available from the Government of Canada network only. Therefore, if you can access this network from home, via VPN to your departmental network or a government-issued Blackberry, you can access them. You can access GCcollab at home since it is available outside of the Government of Canada network.


      • What is simplified sign-on?

        About the GCTools > FAQs

        Simplified Sign-on allows users to log in to GCpedia and GCconnex simultaneously.


        First, you have to link your GCpedia and GCconnex accounts (you only do this once). Once your accounts are linked, when you log in to GCconnex you will automatically be logged in to GCpedia, and vice versa. When you’re logging from GCpedia, use the “Simplified Sign-on” button to take advantage of the Simplified Sign-on feature.  

        For more information, see the Simplified Sign-on tutorial.

      About the GCTools

      • What are the rules regarding Official Languages?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools

        The same rules apply on the GCTools that apply in any other aspect of your work. If there is a document or information that you normally would have translated if distributing by e-mail or hardcopies in person, then you should do so if posting to the GCTools are not meant to be used to circumvent your official languages obligations, all the same policies apply online as they do in the offline world.  


        Determining your target audience is important. People should manage the content they post to the GCTools as if it were an email or a contribution in a meeting. In some meetings, members agree to work in French only or in English only. This is something you have the right to decide as a committee. It might be important (or mandatory) that documents or messages be available in both official languages, for example when conducting a government-wide consultation.


        Employees are free to contribute in the language of their choice in all aspects of their work, including on the GCTools. That means that if you have a French page/section and an English page/section that are asking for people to provide comments or feedback, they will never be the mirror of one another. And that is acceptable. There is no obligation to have the “work-in-progress” translated. The end product should however be made available in both official languages.


        Be aware as well that not all public servants have the same official languages obligations. For example, some organizations are unilingual depending on the region they are based out of. In these circumstances, all the content they might post to the GCTools would be in one language only. Again, the same rules that apply offline also apply online.


      • Is the content of the GCTools “ATIPable”?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools
        Yes, as is everything we do or use in the public service.


        You will never receive a question like “I want to know what has been done on file X in GCpedia”. Instead, an Access to Information request is probably going to have a question like “I want to know what has been done on file X”. Then you would have to go through your emails, paper documents (even your own personal hand written notes), filing cabinet, electronic document system, AND the GCTools. They are another place to verify on the checklist. 


        Don’t forget, if any content on GCpedia, GCconnex, or GCcollab has business value or led to business value or decisions, it should have been saved in your official repository, as stipulated in our IM guidelines and policies. Therefore, that content would already be in an ”ATIPable” tool. 


        GCpedia, GCconnex, and GCcollab are meant for transitory information, idea generation, or for sharing purpose. They are not official repositories. 


      • Who has ownership of the content?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools
        Each individual employee is responsible for what she or he posts. If the post were to be inappropriate or violate the terms and conditions of use of the GCTools a group administrator would not be held responsible.


        However, good practice for group administrators is to actively moderate and monitor comments and activity within your group. You are also free to have your own rules of engagement for a group that you administer.


      • Who ensures accuracy on content?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools
        Sharing incorrect or outdated information can happen anywhere, not just on the GCTools. 


        As employees communicate and collaborate, it becomes much easier to spot mistakes, pieces of misinformation, and other inaccuracies. In theory, the more we all use GCpedia, GCconnex, and GCcollab, the more likely the information there will be more up-to-date and relevant than information we find in more traditional sources (as Wikipedia has proven to us in the world of encyclopaedias!). 


        If you have doubts about the accuracy, we encourage you to edit the page or start a conversation about it. Trust your instinct, and confirm with a reliable source. Then edit the page for the benefit of other users. In case of disagreement with the original author, don’t get into  a “flame war”. Do as you would do during a meeting or an informal conversation in the kitchen: agree to disagree.

         

        People will understand that any content on the tool is not from an authoritative source and should be taken as is it: a work in progress. 


        The GCTools team does not centrally monitor content posted on GCpedia, GCconnex, GCcollab. All teams or committees have to set their own engagement rules as to who will monitor content posted within their groups or pages. 


      • How can I learn about the history of the GCTools?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools
        Information on the GCTools is available on GCpedia, along with resources and communication products that provide information on the history of the GCTools.


      • Will access to the GCTools from personal devices be available in the future?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools
        The GCTools team is currently looking into enabling secure access from personal devices. This is a common user request.


      • Why open source software?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools
        • Access to code and applications is easy (no procurement process, no licensing costs).
        • They are easy to install.
        • There is very little investment involved. Installing new modules is made easy and flexible.


      • What is a GCTools Ambassador?

        About the GCTools > About the GCTools

        A GCTools Ambassador is a volunteer from a government department or region who promote GCpedia, GCconnex, and GCcollab by providing support to departmental or regional teams in understanding how the GCTools can enhance their work.


        In 2016-2017, the Ambassadors Network consisted of 240 ambassadors located in 50 departments and regions.


        The role of a GCTools Ambassador is to:

        • Promote the GCTools within their organization, communities and across the Public Service

        • Be willing to proactively seek out opportunities to promote the GCTools

        • Relay the feedback you get from the audiences to us

        • Build your own network of ambassadors within your organization (it is more fun if you aren’t doing it alone!)


        How to get involved:

        • Obtain approval from your manager as being part of the GCTools Ambassadors Network will involve some of your time during business hours. Request to join the GCconnex closed group

        • Add your name to the Ambassadors' list

        • Register to one of the orientation sessions (see Event Calendar for dates and registration)

        • Add the Ambassador badge to your GCconnex avatar

        • Add the GC Tools Ambassador Userbox to your GCpedia profile.


        How to find an Ambassador: Refer to our Find an Ambassador page.


        No Ambassador in your organization? Contact our Help Desk.


        For more information, please see our Ambassadors Network page.

      About GCconnex

      • What is GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        GCconnex is a professional networking and collaborative workspace for all public servants, allowing them to connect and share information, leveraging the power of networking towards a more effective and efficient public service.


        It features dynamic online communities where public servants can collaborate on projects, blog, chat via instant messaging, carry on discussions, ask and answer each other's questions about anything from learning to technology, such as WebEx. It acts as a professional platform to create your professional C.V., share ideas on The Wire, and connect you with people and information that you need. Also, GCconnex groups can be open to anyone interested in a particular subject area, or closed, where users can request to join and must be accepted by the group owners, to invitation-only, where only those invited to join will even be able to see that the group exists.


        Register here.


      • Who can use GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Users are free to use GCconnex as they see fit, within the codes of conduct of their respective organizations.


        Canadian public servants of departments and agencies of the Government of Canada with access to SCNet can access GCconnex.


        Register for GCconnex here.

      • What can we do with GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Enhance Team Dynamics

        Having access to GCconnex empowers users to make suggestions, interact openly and surface issues and ideas to improve the work environment. Users can search and find like-minded individuals and enhance collaboration, networking and best practices, while contributing to the creation of stronger communities. Additionally, by responding to requests or promoting their knowledge, they can engage their passions, sometimes outside of the formal boundaries of their roles.


        Effective Meetings

        GCconnex can help enhance effective meetings, facilitate people working and collaborate on projects in between meetings. Using a GCconnex group and/or the Chatroom functionalities, meetings can be replaced altogether.


        Share Content

        GCconnex can be great places to draft, store, and distribute meeting agendas and minutes; improving sharing and access to these documents or tools across worksites and regions. In addition, users can upload related materials such as presentations and handouts, keeping everything together. By using group discussions, no-one gets left out of email chains, reply-to-all discussions stop clogging your email and you have a record of all changes and contributors.


        Centralize Content

        GCconnex can be used to centralize the information and organization of an entire project. Not only could it store meeting notes and provide brainstorming space, it can organize a project into an open environment with two-way communication. By putting key documents on GCconnex and encouraging open collaboration, this reduces the risk of key documents being lost in someone’s email folder or losing key information when a contributor moves on.


        Manage Knowledge and Organize Your Team

        Maintaining team information within a GCconnex group enables new employees to easily access information, eliminating redundant processes, such as having someone email them the information. Because of the group functionality, it is easy for someone new to identify their new teammates, send messages, ask questions to the group, and read earlier discussions, etc. GCconnex can be your one-stop location for information and collaboration.


        There are many ways to get started. Here are some simple suggestions:

        • Join a group and participate in the group’s discussions – you’ll find people whose ideas you agree with, and others that challenge some of your thinking. If you decide you’d like to continue a conversation with just one individual, making them a colleague will give you the option to chat with them in real time or receive notification messages of their GCconnex activity, or you can message them directly.

        • Comment on postings on The Wire – answer a question or support a comment with a “thumbs up”. Expressing yourself online may feel odd at first, so start with small steps if you need to. It will become second nature if you keep it up.

        • Post on "The Wire" - an article, a news item, an observation of 140 characters or less (just like Twitter – but internal to the GC). Your post will allow others to know a bit about what you’re interested in.

        • Share your thoughts in groups you belong to, or write a blog to share.

        • Ask questions, respond to people - don't be afraid to show what you don't know, and show what you do know - share your expertise.


        Register for GCconnex here.


      • Do I need permission to use GCconnex? Who has access to GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        No. You do NOT require permission to access GCconnex. 


        The system can only create GCconnex accounts using a valid Government of Canada email address ending in gc.ca or canada.ca. 


        Register for GCconnex here. 




      • Is there a cost to using GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        No. GCconnex is free to use for all public servants. Get started here.


      • Can't I just browse anonymously? Why should I create an account?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Unfortunately, you can’t browse GCconnex anonymously. All users must be registered to browse. All registered users can browse, network, share information and collaborate.


        Register for GCconnex here.


      • What is Jobs Marketplace?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Jobs Marketplace is a public service-wide Internet forum, created within  GCconnex, that enables employees to network professionally across departments. Jobs Marketplace is intended for at-level mobility (e.g. indeterminate and term deployments, secondments, and assignments), as well as casual employment, students seeking employment opportunities, micro-mission opportunities as well as a reference page to other sources of talent that managers and HR professionals may wish to explore, including active pools from other departments. Jobs Marketplace can also be used as a tool to facilitate alternations during workforce adjustment situations.

         Jobs Marketplace facilitates people management by improving access for managers to inventories of motivated employees ready and willing to take on new challenges. It also enables employee engagement, discussion and learning, both through the potential opportunities that Jobs Marketplace offers, and through the use of the tool itself.

        The Jobs Marketplace has a new automated matching tool, the Career ConneXions Opportunities Platform. This is a tool that quickly matches at-level mobility (i.e. micro-missions and job swapping) and development (i.e. mentoring and job shadowing) opportunities with talented employees by leveraging the content in employees’ GCconnex profiles. Employees are encouraged to “opt in” to the professional development and at-level mobility opportunities in their profiles to take full advantage of this tool.


         Jobs Marketplace is being enhanced to make it a one-stop shop for managers and employees to navigate new features for public service staffing, resourcing and development. Check Jobs Marketplace regularly to take advantage of the new features and information! 


      • What is the Wire?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Similar to Twitter, the Wire is a micro-blog. Users can post text with a 140 character limit to easily and quickly share information. You can search the Wire by hashtags, keywords, and @mentions and you will receive a notification when a fellow user tags you in a Wire post or conversation in a discussion, comment, or blog.


        Post an event you're excited about, promote your group, or pose a question to the GCconnex community. Write on the Wire today.


      • Are there administrative functions that managers can access on GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        There are no explicit administrative functions that managers can access. However, any user who creates a group in GCconnex or is designated as a group operator will have administrative privileges for that group including content options, membership, and visibility. Managers can create a group and acquire these privileges. 


        As a group owner, you can set the default content access level to be open to all users or only available to group members. While moderation issues are rare, group owners can also manage content within a group setting. 


      • What about Official Languages?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        We respect the Official Languages Act and are committed to providing all functionalities of GCconnex in both official languages. When posting content, you should consider your role within your organization, your work responsibilities and your intended audience. We recommend that official content and content intended for broad dissemination be provided in both official languages as a best practice.



      • How secure/safe is GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        The GCTools team routinely monitors network traffic to identify unauthorized attempts to upload or change information, or otherwise cause damage. We track network traffic information such as, the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the computer, the date and time of visits, and the pages visited. We make no attempt to link the information with the identity of individuals unless an attempt to damage the site has been detected.


        For public servants, only material that is classified Protected A or below should be posted on the GCTools.


      • Is GCconnex vulnerable to inaccurate information?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Given that any registered user can add content, of course it is possible for biased, out-of-date, or incorrect information to be posted. You are encouraged to help by correcting information, validating content, and providing useful references. Thus, the overall accuracy of information on GCconnex is improving all the time.


        It is the responsibility of each individual who posts content to maintain its accuracy. There is no way of enforcing accuracy. Each individual must be trusted to be effective in sharing information. It should be noted however that any user can and should correct that which they know is wrong. As a reader you need to use your judgment about the credibility, timeliness, reliability, and accuracy of what you read on GCconnex.


      • Is GCconnex vulnerable to vandals?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Like all virtual workspaces where individuals are invited to participate and make contributions, there is the risk that an individual could disrupt the creative process or vandalize the product itself. However, there are a number of mechanisms in place to mitigate this risk and incentives to dissuade inappropriate or destructive behavior within the GCconnex community.


        1. GCconnex users are required to use their real names and professional email addresses when registering. Pseudonyms or 'handles' are not permitted.

        2. GCconnex is a business tool. It is unlikely that an individual will risk their professional reputation for the sake of mischief.

        3. Given that everything that happens in GCconnex is fully documented and tied back to a unique user account, it is easy to identify someone who vandalizes or posts inappropriate content on a GCconnex page.


        When using GCconnex, public servants are expected to abide by the Value and Ethics Code for the Public Service.


      • What happens if someone posts inappropriate information on GCconnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        All content is attributable as all entries are automatically date and time stamped with the contributors valid e-mail address. Inappropriate content can be removed very quickly. Participants of GCconnex that come across inappropriate content are encouraged to bring it to the attention of the GCTools team.


        If necessary, GCconnex administrators can remove the inappropriate content and suspend a user’s account.


      • How does GCconnex protect my privacy?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        Collection

        • All personal information within GCconnex is considered to be voluntarily provided and any use or disclosure will be governed by the rights of access to, correction of and protection of personal information under the Privacy Act.
        • GCconnex users are advised that all information / content posted to a federal government wiki, blog or other collaborative site is subject to the provisions of the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act. This implies that information may be accessed and disclosed in response to a request under either of these Acts.
        • For maximum privacy protection, it is recommended that users do not post personal information such as photographs, home addresses, resumes etc., as this information would then be available to all users. Note however that the Privacy Act does not require any protection for certain types of personal information such as is relevant to the positions and functions of public servants therefore, this type of personal information can be posted and is in fact encouraged. This includes such things as an employee's departmental subject matter area of expertise, his or her work coordinates (including email address and government-issued telephone and cell phone number), his/her title and classification and views and/or opinions he/she would normally express in the course of fulfilling his/her duties.
        • When a contribution is made, the user needs to be logged-in and GCconnex (Elgg) stores the contribution information which includes user name, and the date and time of the action.


        Usage

        In order for individuals to contribute content or view closed content, they are required to have a valid GCconnex account. The registration process requires the collection of certain personal information, namely user name, real name, and email address.


        Disclosure

        Individuals with access to the internal Government of Canada network (SC-Net) may be able to browse and read some content on GCconnex without the need to register depending on the privacy settings for each piece of content.

        Your personal information is not shared, sold, rented, traded, or otherwise disclosed to any outside third party except with your consent or where authorized and or required by law.


        Retention

        Personal information is retained by GCconnex only so long as required by law or as is reasonable to fulfill the purposes for which it has been collected.


      • Is GCconnex open to Access to Information requests?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex
        Note that GCconnex can be accessed by members of the public pursuant to an Access to Information request, by the Members of Parliament, the Senate and their staff in both the Government and Opposition, and that non-Government of Canada users may be invited to access GCconnex for special projects.


        The GC Tools are your digital workplace. We hope you take as much pride in it as we do.

      • Is polling in GCconnex considered public opinion research (POR)?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        GCconnex does not make something POR or not, it is how it is used. It is entirely possible to use the polling feature on GCconnex in a manner that would be considered POR, as well as a manner that isn’t.


        It is up to each user to ensure that they are using the tool in a way that is policy compliant, and if a potential use of the polling function would constitute POR they should seek the appropriate approvals with their departmental Communications.


      • Can we create groups on GCconnex that are for informal workplace activities?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        The rules that apply in the “offline” world apply in the “online” world.


        Here is a rule of thumb: if you would make a reservation of a board/meeting room at work for your group, then you may create a group in GCconnex. If you would be comfortable using other "work tools" (emails, boardroom, etc.) provided by the employer to share the same information, without getting into trouble with your management, then GCconnex is perfectly fine. You’re just bringing the conversation somewhere else, on another work tool.  For example:  

        •  Curling club that meets outside of work? No GCconnex group. 
        •  Book club on work-related topics, OL practice during lunch? A GCconnex group is OK.
        •  Health and wellness activities (a meditation group for example) – even after-hours? Yes, if they are supported through internal committees or workplace initiatives. 


        As long as the group is supported by the workplace


        The permissible uses above of GCconnex would actually make a lot of sense, since this kind of group would be a great place to put the required resources that new members to your group would need to get started (instead of having to email them separately each time a new member joins), calendar items for lunchtime sessions (which would avoid email overload), and members would have the flexibility to share articles or other information related to the topic.


        You may also use the Code of Values and Ethics as a guide. 


      • What about colleagues who have left (retired or elsewhere)? Should we delete their profile?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        In GCconnex, if we delete an account, everything that person did is lost.


        Don’t forget, even if someone leaves the public service for a while, it doesn’t mean they are never coming back (students for example). By keeping their profile, we allow them to start where they have left off. Also, the content in a retired colleague’s profile can still be relevant and useful. Deleting the profile would delete this useful information…  


        In the case of someone who leaves – for good or for a while – we suggest (until we find a solution for this) that they post that they are retired or have left in a customized widget. 


        To keep activity to a minimum:

        • Delete all contact info and add a note in your description that you have left the public service
        • Remove your avatar 
        • Remove all your colleagues OR (if you know you will be back) turn of all Notifications
        • Leave all of the groups you are a member of OR (if you know you will be back) turn off all Group Notifications
        • If you are the admin of a group, ask the owner to transfer the admin powers to another member of the group
        • If you are the owner of a group, transfer the ownership to another member of your group


      • Can my team use a generic e-mail for our group on GCConnex?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex
        GCconnex is a professional social networking platform where human connections and trust are key. People relate more to (and interact more with) individuals than to (with) generic mailbox. This is why we strongly encourage you to have an individual as the owner of a group. 


        This being said, we understand that in some cases (if your group serves as an intranet-type of communications), you will want to share the responsibilities that come with community management.

        Here is an option: assign as many group operators as you want. They have the exact same administrative rights as the group owner (except for deleting the group). 


        Still not convinced? If you decide to use a generic email for your group, make sure it’s clear who is behind it. Do like big companies do on Twitter for example: add the initial of the person communicating/responding with the generic persona (ex: ^AL)


      • What is the difference between a group blog and group discussion?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex

        A group blog is meant for when you want to share your thoughts on something or information on a topic. Compared to a discussion thread, it’s closer to a one-sided communications feature. Your readers might comment, and that is a good thing. The objective of the blog is not necessarily to get feedback (although, you probably will). Blogs usually include a call to action or a “stake in the ground” giving information what this group is about: sign-up for this! Register to that! Tell me what you think! Donate! Blogs are available in groups or in individual profiles, which means you can blog in a personal fashion. 


        A group discussion, on the other hand, is meant to be a two-sided communications feature. Here, you want to receive answers! Any member of a group can post a discussion topic, give context, ask questions. Group members will reply to the original question, or to comments made by others in response to the original question. It then becomes a continuous back and forth discussion of the group members’ ideas, opinions, questions and interpretations of the topic at hand.


      • I receive too many notifications. What can I do?

        About the GCTools > About GCconnex
        • Try our new GCconnex notifications digest.The notifications digest can be used to receive a daily or weekly email that provides a summary of the activities to which you are subscribed. Hover over your "Notifications" link at the top of every page and click on the gear icon. Enable your notifications digest!
        • Turn off some of your Group Notifications. Keep the notifications on for the group that most interest you. For the others, go back and visit them once in a while to see what has happened. Go to Settings, and then Group notifications. For more on how to set your group notifications, check out the tutorials here.
        • You may also choose to turn off notifications for your colleagues’ activity. You can turn the notifications off in bulk, or customize per colleague. Go to Settings, and then Notifications. For more on how to set your colleagues notifications, check out the tutorials here.
        • OR: Keep the notifications on, but sort messages as they arrive in your Inbox! Set an automated rule in Outlook that will send all email notifications from GCconnex to a specific folder, therefore you can create a rule that applies specifically to that e-mail address.
        • Check the blog post Filtering GCconnex Mail Notifications for Groups by Dave Sampson.

      About GCcollab

      • What is GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        GCcollab is your professional collaboration platform, connecting you to information and people from across the Government of Canada. GCcollab is open to students and academics from all Canadian universities and colleges as well as federal, provincial and territorial public servants. GCcollab is a major step toward a more innovative, open, and collaborative way of identifying, exploring and co-creating the policy and research agendas.

         

        GCcollab is expected to increase the depth and breadth of data and information sharing between the academic and public sector communities to support improved deliberation on policy issues. GCcollab is also expected to build a more connected, relevant and responsive cohort of public servants, students and academics.

         

        GCcollab is predicted to also contribute to a culture change as the existing public service is provided better access to emerging research, technologies, and communication approaches, and conversely, as academics and students improve their understanding of the policy, program and research development processes.

         

        This cloud-based collaboration platform will also be leveraged to promote recruitment opportunities to those interested in joining the federal public service. To learn, connect and share, join GCcollab.

         

        For a complete list of organizations participating on GCcollab, click here.


      • Who can use GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Users are free to use GCcollab as they see fit, within the codes of conduct of their respective organizations.


        Academics and students of Canadian post-secondary institution selected to participate on the GCcollab pilot project are eligible to participate. Employees of departments and agencies of the Government of Canada with access to SCNet can access GCcollab.


      • What can we do with GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Almost any subject area that requires the sharing, use and collaborative development of information can be supported by GCcollab.


        Academics can use GCcollab to connect and network with their research or policy counterparts. Students can ask questions to support their course work and research, or to inquire about potential employment opportunities. Public Servants can leverage GCcollab to identify talent, support their on-going research, find their subject-related counterparts or supplement public consultations processes.


        There are other areas of opportunity being demonstrated by GCcollab users every day. Be bold and creative – put GCcollab to good use and give it a try.

      • Is there a cost to using GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        No. GCcollab is free to use for all participants – students, academics and public servants.


      • Do I need permission to use GCcollab? Who has access to GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        No. You do NOT require permission to access GCcollab.


        Academics and students from the select post-secondary institutions from across Canada have access to GCcollab using their school email addresses.


        Public servants from most departments and agencies of the Government of Canada have access to GCcollab.


      • Can I browse anonymously?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Unfortunately, no you cannot browse GCcollab anonymously. You need to create an account. All users must be registered even to browse. Register here.


        All registered users can browse, network, share information and collaborate.


      • What is the Wire?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Similar to Twitter, the Wire is a micro-blog where users can post text with a 140 character limit to easily and quickly share information. You can search the Wire by hashtags, keywords, and @mentions and you will receive a notification when a fellow user tags you in a Wire post or conversation in a discussion, comment, or blog.


        Post an event you’re excited about, promote your group, or pose a question to the GCcollab community. Write on The Wire today.


      • What is a GCTools Ambassador?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        A GCTools Ambassador is a volunteer from a government department or region who promotes GCconnex, Gcpedia, and GCcollab by providing support to departmental or regional teams in understanding how the GCTools can enhance their work.


        In 2016-2017, the Ambassadors Network consisted of 240 ambassadors located in 50 departments and regions.


        The role of a GCTools Ambassador is to:

        • Promote the GCTools within their organization, communities and across the Public Service

        • Be willing to proactively seek out opportunities to promote the GCTools

        • Relay the feedback you get from the audiences to us

        • Build your own network of ambassadors within your organization (it is more fun if you aren’t doing it alone!)


        How to get involved:

        • Obtain approval from your manager as being part of the GCTools Ambassadors Network will involve some of your time during business hours. Request to join the GCconnex closed group

        • Add your name to the Ambassadors' list

        • Register to one of the orientation sessions (see Event Calendar for dates and registration)

        • Add the Ambassador badge to your GCconnex avatar

        • Add the GC Tools Ambassador Userbox to your GCpedia profile.


        How to find an Ambassador: Refer to our Find an Ambassador page.


        No Ambassador in your organization? Contact our Help Desk.


        For more information, please see our Ambassadors Network page.


      • What about Official Languages?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        We respect the Official Languages Act and are committed to providing all functionalities of GCcollab in both official languages. When posting content, you should consider your role within your organization, your work responsibilities and your intended audience. We recommend that official content and content intended for broad dissemination be provided in both official languages as a best practice.


      • How secure/safe is GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        We routinely monitor network traffic to identify unauthorized attempts to upload or change information, or otherwise cause damage. We track network traffic information such as, the Internet Protocol (IP) address of the computer, the date and time of visits, and the pages visited. We make no attempt to link the information with the identity of individuals unless an attempt to damage the site has been detected.


        For public servants, only material that is classified Protected A or below should be posted on the GC Tools.


      • Is GCcollab vulnerable to inaccurate information?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Given that any registered user can add content, it is possible for biased, out-of-date, or incorrect information to be posted. You are encouraged to help by correcting information, validating content, and providing useful references. Thus, the overall accuracy of information on GCcollab is improving all the time.


        It is the responsibility of each individual who posts content to maintain its accuracy. There is no way of enforcing accuracy. Each individual must be trusted to be effective in sharing information. It should be noted however that any user can and should correct that which they know is wrong. As a reader you need to use your judgment about the credibility, timeliness, reliability, and accuracy of what you read on GCcollab.


      • Is GCcollab vulnerable to vandals?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Like all virtual workspaces where individuals are invited to participate and make contributions, there is the risk that an individual could disrupt the creative process or vandalize the product itself. However, there are a number of mechanisms in place to mitigate this risk and incentives to dissuade inappropriate or destructive behavior within the GCcollab community.


        1. GCcollab users are required to use their real names and professional email addresses when registering. Pseudonyms or 'handles' are not permitted.

        2. GCcollab is a business tool. It is unlikely that an individual will risk their professional reputation for the sake of mischief.

        3. Given that everything that happens in GCcollab is fully documented and tied back to a unique user account, it is easy to identify someone who vandalizes or posts inappropriate content on a GCcollab page.


        When using GCcollab, academics and students are expected to behave responsibly in accordance with the code(s) of conduct administered by their respective post-secondary institution. Whereas public servants are expected to abide by the Value and Ethics Code for the Public Service.


      • What happens if someone posts inappropriate information on GCcollab?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        All content is attributable as all entries are automatically date and time stamped with the contributors valid e-mail address. Inappropriate content can be removed very quickly.

        Participants of GCcollab that come across inappropriate content are encouraged to bring it to the attention of the GCcollab Team. If necessary, GCcollab administrators can remove the inappropriate content and suspend a user’s account.


      • Is GCcollab open to Access to Information requests?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Note that GCcollab can be accessed by members of the public pursuant to an Access to Information request, by the Members of Parliament, the Senate and their staff in both the Government and Opposition, and that non-Government of Canada users may be invited to access GCcollab in the future.


        For any other questions regarding policies affecting GCcollab, please refer to the Terms and Conditions of Use.


      • Can GCcollab be used by Crown corporations?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        Although it is true that GCcollab is readily available to departments with a “gc.ca” and "canada.ca" email, other organizations can still use GCcollab by accessing SCNet (SecureChannel). The “gc.ca” rule is not entirely accurate; there are many organizations, such as Crown corporations, that do not have emails that end in “gc.ca” but that are still connected to SCNet. The cost of accessing SCNet is not technically or financially out of reach for most organizations.


      • Which software does GCcollab run on?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        GCcollab uses Elgg, an open source social networking software that provides individuals and organizations with the components needed to create an online social environment.


      • What about colleagues who have left (retired or elsewhere)? Should we delete their profile?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        In GCcollab, if we delete an account, everything that person did is lost.


        Don’t forget, even if someone leaves the public service for a while, it doesn’t mean they are never coming back (students for example). By keeping their profile, we allow them to start where they have left off. Also, the content in a retired colleague’s profile can still be relevant and useful. Deleting the profile would delete this useful information.


        To keep activity to a minimum:

        • Delete all contact info and add a note in your description that you have left the public service
        • Remove your avatar 
        • Remove all your colleagues OR (if you know you will be back) turn of all Notifications
        • Leave all of the groups you are a member of OR (if you know you will be back) turn off all Group Notifications
        • If you are the admin of a group, ask the owner to transfer the admin powers to another member of the group
        • If you are the owner of a group, transfer the ownership to another member of your group


      • What is the difference between a group blog and group discussion?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab
        A group blog is meant for when you want to share your thoughts on something or information on a topic. Compared to a discussion thread, it’s closer to a one-sided communications feature. Your readers might comment, and that is a good thing. The objective of the blog is not necessarily to get feedback (although, you probably will). Blogs usually include a call to action or a “stake in the ground” giving information what this group is about: sign-up for this! Register to that! Tell me what you think! Donate! Blogs are available in groups or in individual profiles, which means you can blog in a personal fashion. 


        A group discussion, on the other hand, is meant to be a two-sided communications feature. Here, you want to receive answers! Any member of a group can post a discussion topic, give context, ask questions. Group members will reply to the original question, or to comments made by others in response to the original question. It then becomes a continuous back and forth discussion of the group members’ ideas, opinions, questions and interpretations of the topic at hand.


      • I receive too many notifications. What can I do?

        About the GCTools > About GCcollab

        This is a good problem to have; it means you are a member of very active groups, or are colleagues with keen users of GCcollab! Don’t worry, there are many solutions.

        • Turn off some of your Group Notifications. Keep the notifications on for the group that most interest you. For the others, go back and visit them once in a while to see what has happened. Hover over the bell (notifications) icon, and then click on the gear icon.
        • You may also choose to turn off notifications for your colleagues’ activity. Hover over the bell (notifications) icon, and then click on the gear icon.
        • OR: Keep the notifications on, but sort messages as they arrive in your Inbox! Set an automated rule in Outlook that will send all email notifications from GCcollab to a specific folder, therefore you can create a rule that applies specifically to that e-mail address.

      About GCpedia

      • What is GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        GCpedia is an internal wiki used by the Government of Canada, for collaboration and knowledge sharing. GCpedia is only accessible to Government of Canada employees.The user base is potentially 250,000 people, from over 150 departments and agencies. Users must be registered if they wish to add or modify content, so that all contributions are attributable


        GCpedia has been used as a platform to take, publish, and distribute meeting minutes, to create project status dashboards, to collaboratively author interdepartmental papers, to brainstorm, and to create wiki-based briefing books. GCpedia is managed by the GCTools Team, which also manages GCconnex and GCcollab. The team is part of Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat.


      • Who can use GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        Only Government of Canada departments and agencies with access to SCNet can access GCpedia. Please also note that the GC 2.0 Tools can be accessed by members of the public pursuant to an Access to Information request, by the Members of Parliament, the Senate and their staff in both the Government and Opposition, and that non-Government of Canada users may be invited to access the Tools for special projects.

      • Why should I create an account? Can I browse anonymously?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        Registered users can:

        • Edit pages
        • Start new pages, including their own user page
        • Rename pages
        • Upload images
        • Keep a watchlist to track changes made on articles of interest
        • Easily review their own contributions
        • Customize their own signatures when they sign on talk pages by going to their preferences

      • What can we do with GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        Almost any area of practice within the public service that requires the sharing, use and collaborative development of documents can be supported by GCpedia.


        To date, it has been used to record meeting minutes, organize car pools, raise funds for United Way with a silent auction, establish terms of reference for interdepartmental committees, and support communities of practice in areas like Aboriginal affairs, information management, and learning.


        There are other areas of opportunity being demonstrated by GCpedia users every day. Be bold and creative and put GCpedia to good use - try GCpedia today.


      • Why is GCpedia different than other collaboration tools?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        Like most wikis, GCpedia does not support 'private' spaces. As such it is meant for sharing unprotected information in an ongoing fashion. GCpedia is meant to be a steadily developing information resource accessible by everyone on the Government of Canada network.


        Through GCpedia, departments are empowered to share information that they believe other agencies across the Government of Canada would benefit from receiving, and get feedback in return--including serendipitous input from unexpected quarters of the federal government.


      • Do I need permission from anyone to use GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        No, just behave in line with the code of conduct and the Terms and Conditions of Use. 


        Tens of thousands of Public Servants have registered accounts on GCpedia and thousands of GCpedians across the country use it every day as part of their work. It has proven its value as an indispensable work tool and many organizations have developed approaches for using GCpedia that give explicit approval to employees for using the wiki.


        Keep in mind that secure, confidential, and sensitive information does not belong on GCpedia.


      • Do we need to consult TBS prior to commencing our project?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        No, you do not need to seek the permission of TBS  to use GCpedia as long as you abide by the code of conduct and the Terms of Use.


      • Why can't we have our departmental pages on GCpedia that aren't accessible to other departments?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        All pages on GCpedia can be seen by all users. GCpedia sysops can protect a page from editing if there is a strong justification for doing so (i.e. protecting a template that is used thousands of times on the wiki).


        If you need your page protected to prevent other users from editing it, ask yourself whether it belongs on GCpedia in the first place. A simple alternative to protecting a page is to use the template {{protected}}, which asks users to refrain from editing the page.


      • Is there a cost to using GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        No. Members of the Chief Information Officer Council (CIOC) provide funding to the GC2.0 Tools Team to support operations of GCpedia.

      • Can GCpedia support every employee in the federal government?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        Yes, federal government employees total approximately 250,000 Canada-wide, which is not a lot of users in the large scheme of wiki/web use.


        Pages are lightweight in terms of memory use because they contain “thin” media-wiki code. Maximum capacity (all Government of Canada) was considered in the planning stage.


      • How secure/safe is GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        As secure as any internal government website, email or shared drive. GCpedia is running on Shared Services Canada production hardware that is backed up every day. TBS also regularly backs up the site. Pages are also protected from user deletion through the “page history” tab on the site. If someone deletes content or a page, the page history remains, which allows a user to bring up previous page versions. All edits on GCpedia are fully attributable to the editor.

         Mediawiki software is designed to be open, and if a high level of access control is required it may not be the best solution. Problem edits are rarely an issue on GCpedia and that simply posting a notice asking others to refrain from editing the page usually works. Simply put, the idea of blocking contributions runs contrary to the idea of mass collaboration.

        GCpedia will never be a place for “sensitive” information.


      • Is GCpedia vulnerable to inaccurate information?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        Given that any registered user can edit any article, it is, of course, possible for biased, out-of-date, or incorrect information to be posted. However, because there are so many other people accessing the content and monitoring contributions using the recent changes page, incorrect information is usually corrected quickly. Thus, the overall accuracy of information on GCpedia is improving all the time. You are encouraged to help by correcting information, validating content, and providing useful references.

        It is the responsibility of each individual who creates a page to maintain its accuracy. There is no way of enforcing accuracy. Each individual must be trusted to be effective in sharing information. It should be noted however that any user can and should correct that which they know is wrong.

        As a reader you need to use your judgment about the credibility, timeliness, reliability, and accuracy of what you read on GCpedia. Looking at when the page was created (via the 'history' tab), and examining how many people have edited the page will help you judge what you read. Individual users edit histories can also be scrutinized to see the kind and quality of information they are providing to the GCpedia community.

         As GCpedia has now been in production since 2008, redundant, outdated and trivial content is now increasing. An initiative called  GCpedia ROT reduction is comprised of volunteer GCpedians who are committed to helping to improve the quality of GCpedia content. 


      • Is GCpedia vulnerable to vandals?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        Like all physical and virtual workspaces where individuals are invited to participate and make contributions, there is the risk that an individual could disrupt the creative process or vandalize the product itself. However, there are a number of mechanisms in place to mitigate this risk and incentives to dissuade inappropriate or destructive behavior within the GCpedia community. 


        1. GCpedia users are required to use their real names and work email addresses when registering. Pseudonyms or 'handles' are not permitted
        2. A feature of the MediaWiki software that forms the basis of GCpedia is that it logs and tracks all changes to content on the site. In fact, each page has a 'history' tab that itemizes who changed a document and when. The software also enables version comparisons to highlight specific changes made over a period of time.
        3. GCpedia is a business tool. It is unlikely that an individual will risk their professional reputation for the sake of mischief.
        4. Given that everything that happens in GCpedia is fully documented and tied back to a unique user account and a secure Government of Canada Server, it is easy to identify someone who vandalizes a page on GCpedia.


        When using GCconnex, public servants are expected to abide by the Value and Ethics Code for the Public Service.

      • What happens if someone posts inappropriate information on GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        Wikis tend to be self policing and inappropriate content gets removed or corrected very quickly. TBS can take down inappropriate content within 24 hours.


        All content is attributable as all entries are automatically date and time stamped with the contributors valid e-mail address. So if someone posts something inappropriate their reputation suffers. For the most part this seems to work. Other organizations using this model have experienced little or no issues, and we have not experienced any to date. If necessary, GCpedia administrators and others involved can remove the inappropriate content and suspend a user’s account.


      • What about Official Languages?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        We respect the Official Languages Act and are committed to providing all functionalities of the Tools in both official languages. When posting content, you should consider your role within your organization, your work responsibilities and your intended audience. We advise that official content and content intended for broad dissemination be provided in both official languages as a best practice.


        For more information, see GCpedia:Official Languages and Internal Online Collaborative Tools Guidance/Official Languages


      • Is GCpedia open to Access to Information requests?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        Yes. See Wiki Access to Information Act and Privacy Act Guidelines and Internal Online Collaborative Tools Guidance/Information Management & ATIP.


      • Can GCpedia be used by Crown corporations?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        Although it is true that GCpedia is readily available to departments with a “gc.ca” and "@Canada.ca" email, other organizations can still use GCpedia by accessing SCNet (SecureChannel). The “gc.ca” rule is not entirely accurate; there are many organizations, such as Crown corporations, that do not have emails that end in “gc.ca” but that are still connected to SCNet.


         The cost of accessing SCNet is not technically or financially out of reach for most organizations; however, access goes through PWGSC. For more information, refer to this GCpedia page explaining the Secure Channel.


      • Which wiki software does GCpedia run on?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        GCpedia uses MediaWiki software, the same software as Wikipedia, to facilitate collaborative editing and storage of page histories.


        For more information on MediaWiki, see the MediaWiki web site.


      • What is the largest file size I can upload to GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        The system only allows files smaller than 32MB to be uploaded, so its best to compress your file to 32MB then upload to GCpedia.


      • What about colleagues who have left (retired or elsewhere)? Should we delete their profile?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia

        In GCpedia, this is not an issue. We can remove a user profile and keep or merge the information they created.

      • Can anyone edit my page in GCpedia?

        About the GCTools > About GCpedia
        Yes. That is how a wiki is meant to work. We know, it takes some getting used to! Let’s face it, people have better things to do than mess up your content! But if someone was messing up you page “just for fun” you could easily find out who they are: all edits are attributable and linked to a user (with a work email address).


        Also, GCpedia keeps a history of all edits made on a page. If you don’t like a change someone has made, it’s easy to revert to an earlier version.

Pour commencer

  • Comment puis-je créer un compte GCpédia?

    GCpedia - Documentation d'aide > Pour commencer

    1. Appuyé sur le bouton Créer un compte, qui se trouve au coin supérieur droit de la page GCpedia.



    2. Insérer votre adresse courriel du gouvernement,

        Entré la première partie de votre courriel. Typiquement Prénom.Derniernom (exemple: Robert.Trambley)



    3. Sélectionner votre domaine de courriel dans la liste du menu déroulant.

        *Si vous ne voyez pas votre domaine dans la liste, choisissez (Autre..)



    4. Votre nom d'utilisateur sera automatiquement généré par GCpedia, après avoir inséré votre adresse courriel.

        Entré et re-entré un mot de passe sécure.



    5. Examiner les conditions d'utilisation et marquer que vous les reconnaissez et acceptez.




    6. Sélectionner le bouton Créer un compte.

  • Comment puis-je naviguer GCpédia?

    GCpedia - Documentation d'aide > Pour commencer

    Si vous regardez une page sur GCPEDIA, vous trouverez trois grands éléments de navigation, en plus de l'article :


    Barre de navigation

    La barre de navigation s’affiche du côté gauche de la page, sous le logo du site. Vous y trouverez quelques options standard, comme la recherche, la navigation et une boîte à outils. Une option de langue s’affiche sur certaines pages; elle vous permet de basculer d’une page en français à une page en anglais. 


    En cliquant sur le logo du site GCPEDIA, vous revenez à la page principale. Les liens dans la section de navigation qui figure juste en dessous vous amènent aux pages importantes du wiki, comme les modifications récentes ou le téléchargement de fichier.

    Onglets


    En haut de la page se trouvent les onglets relatifs à la page en cours : sa page de discussion associée, l'historique des versions et - le plus important - le lien d'édition.


    Options d'utulisateurs

    Dans le coin supérieur droit vous trouverez soit un lien pour créer un compte ou se connecter (si vous n'êtes pas connecté) ou une collection de liens personnels (si vous êtes connecté), comme un vers votre page utilisateur ou vos préférences.

  • Comment puis-je créer une page nouvelle?

    GCpedia - Documentation d'aide > Pour commencer

    Il existe (au moins) trois façons de créer une page dans GCPEDIA:

    1. A l'aide de la boîte de recherche
    2. À l'aide de la barre d'adresse (URL)
    3. À l'aide du code wiki


    À l'aide de la boîte de recherche

    Lorsque vous effectuez une recherche à l'aide de la boîte de recherche de GCPEDIA, vous obtenez une liste de résultats qui concordent avec les mots clés de votre recherche. Si le segment ou le mot exact de votre recherche ne correspond pas à une page de GCPEDIA, le système vous demandera si vous souhaitez en créer une.


    Par exemple, si vous avez entré « Aide au sujet de GCpedia » et qu’aucune page ne porte ce titre, la page des résultats de recherche indiquera ce qui suit :


    Si vous cliquez sur l’un des liens indiqués en rouge qui figurent dans les résultats de recherche, le système vous présentera la page d’édition où vous pourrez créer la page en question. N'oubliez pas d'intituler votre page en fonction des conventions d'appellation.



    À l'aide de la barre d'adresse (URL)


    Vous pouvez créer une page entrant l'adresse (URL) de la page que vous souhaitez créer à partir de la barre d'adresse de votre navigateur Web.

    Par exemple, pour créer une page intitulée « Aide au sujet de GCpedia » :


    1.     Dans la barre d'adresse de votre navigateur Web, entrez l'URL de la page que vous souhaitez créer (p. ex., voir la boîte ci-après).


     http://www.gcpedia.gc.ca/wiki/Aide au sujet de GCpedia 


    2.     Allez à cette page en appuyant sur Enter, Go ou sur la commande appropriée de votre navigateur.
